Hi Sidhant

Great paper. I have been trying to do much the same thing, exce=
pt
rather than value prediction, I have been creating a trader that
essenti=
ally decides to go short, long or take the 5th ;).  I've had
mixed success,=
 and not had the confidence to actually lay any money
out yet.  It would be=
 interesting to know what input data sets have
you been using for the Forex=
 part of your paper, as I have tried all
sorts of things including technica=
l indicators etc.

Cheers

Matt

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Sidhant Dash =
<sidhantdash@...> wrote:
>
> As part of an undergraduate research project, =
I did implement
something on those lines. 
>    
>   I worked on a NEAT bas=
ed approach to predicting a noisy financial
time series (Yen-USD exchange r=
ate). The original NEAT algorithm was
modified to start with an initial pop=
ulation of 3 different neural
network architectures, which included Elman n=
etworks and MLPs apart
from the normal recurrent networks that NEAT begins =
with. The networks
(winners) produced by NEAT were then put through a conju=
gate gradient
based optimization process, and finally the optimized network=
s were
combined using an ensembling technique to produce the final results.=
 
>    
>   I personally think the local optimization is necessary when we =
are
using NEAT to produce networks to accomplish tasks that require a high
=
degree of precision. It kind of fine tunes the performance of the
networks.=
 Ensembling then is one of the standard tools in the ML
repertoire to produ=
ce results that none of NEAT's 'winner' networks
could individually produce=
. 
>    
>   A detailed project report is posted in the Files section.
>   =
 
>   regards
>   Sidhant
> 
> aklein07 <a.klein@...> wrote:
>           Al=
l,
> 
> Ken's papers mention (at least I think that they do) that (dynamic)=
 
> annealing of mutation rates might be advantageous in order to confine 
=
> global searching after a while to a promising region in search space. 
> =
Having read some papers, I also found indications that a hybrid 
> weight t=
raining algorithm (global search by means of genetic 
> algorithms and loca=
l search using some gradient descent algorithm) 
> might be able to produce=
 better results than genetic algorithm search 
> alone. The reason is, that=
 each type of algorithm performs well 
> mostly only in its specific field.=
 Has anyone further insights into 
> this topic ? Has anyone tried to imple=
ment any of the approaches 
> mentioned ? 
> 
> Also time delay network con=
nections might provide improvements for 
> some model estimation tasks. Has=
 anyone tested / implemented yet any 
> of these ideas ?
> 
> Thanks for an=
y comments,
> Achim
> 
> 
>

e mind allows.
